results.title: Design
results.creator_credit: Kit Laybourne, Mickey Lemle and Time-Life Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Media Probes”.
This film considers various aspects of design. Fashion designer Bill Blass shows how clothes make a statement about the people wearing them and a graphic designer and two production assistants point out the tricks of the trade. The final segment shows how a national motel chain set out to change its corporate logo and then rejected the new image. Hosted by Bill Blass, photographed by Ed Lynch and written by Tony Kahn and Brad Kesden.

results.title: Desert victory
results.creator_credit: Army Film Photographic Unit, Australia. Royal Australian Air Force. Production Unit, David Macdonald and Roy Boulting
results.brief_description: The story of the British Eighth Army’s victory at El Alamein, and its advance commencing on 23rd October, 1942 across nearly 1,400 miles of desert in 80 days to Tripoli. The film begins in the days when Generals Alexander and Montgomery took command. The disposition of the opposed forces and the strategy of both sides are explained by means of diagram. After the break-through at El Alamein the camera follows the advance through Mersa Matruh, Halfaya Pass, Sollum, Tobruk, Benghazi, and El Agheila, to the victory parade in Tripoli. Commentary written by J.L. Hodson. (Awards: Academy award, 1943 Best Documentary)

results.title: Desert tracks
results.creator_credit: Janet Bell, Christopher McCullough and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Desert tracks documents the experience of a diverse range of urban whites on tour in Central Australia. The tour began as an initiative of the Pitjantjatjara people to raise funds to assist in the movement back to the their homelands and maintain their communities, but also to break down racial and cultural barriers. Essential to the tour is the involvement of the whites in the Pitjantjatjara culture, sharing knowledge and learning to survive in the Central Desert.

results.title: Desert storm: the war begins
results.creator_credit: Stacy Jolna and Cable News Network
results.brief_description: This video links CNN news coverage together to tell the compelling tale of the opening chapter of the Persian Gulf War. CNN’s ‘Special Report’ team examines the leaders, the warriors, the diplomatic ploys, the history, and the battle strategems in the early days of the war.

results.title: Desert storm: the victory
results.creator_credit: Stacy Jolna and Cable News Network
results.brief_description: This video from CNN’s ‘Special Reports’ team documents the Persian Gulf War. It examines the failed peacemaking process, military strategy, and combat - the air war, 100-hour ground war and the liberation of Kuwait. The celebration and homecoming of the allied forces are also examined.

results.title: Desert stories (A)
results.creator_credit: Nick Frazer, KOKO P, Channel 0-28 and Lindsay Frazer
results.brief_description: The Pintubi Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory tell stories of the Dreamtime, and other stories of their lives. Also shows the work of the Papunya Aboriginal Settlement Literature Production Centre in recording the Pintubi people in their own language. Care is taken that the oral tradition is retained, when transcribing the stories.

results.title: Desert regions: nomads and traders
results.creator_credit: BFA Educational Media and Wolfgang Bayer
results.brief_description: A comparison between two traditional cultures occupying desert lands and the ways in which both tribes customs are being forced into change. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Desert people
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Ian Dunlop
results.brief_description: Scenes typical of the daily life of Aborigines of the Pintubi tribe in the Western Desert cultural area, showing two families: the first was filmed as they were found living in desert conditions, the second had recently settled at Warburton Mission and demonstrated how they had lived a few months earlier. A shorter version of People of the Australian Western Desert, Pts. l, 2 and 4.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Ian Dunlop

results.title: Desert people
results.creator_credit: William L. Claiborne and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: Shows the importance of water to desert people. Compares the Tuaregs, nomadic people constantly in search of water, with the Hajputs, who are cultivators, running water through an ancient irrigation system by camel power and natural flow. This film has no English dialogue, the images speak for themselves. However, you can hear the Desert people in their native tongue.
